Don't get me wrong, the voice acting and humor is exactly what you see on TV, this is basically a playable South Park episode. I just wish they added some more missions/quests to keep me coming back....TLDR; Get the game on sale. You can beat the entire game in under a day so try to limit yourself to a couple hours at a time to maximze playtime. If you are a South Park fan you will enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												It’s really quite remarkable how South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone have slowly ramped up the shock value over the past 17 years to keep the show sharp. Whether they and developer Obsidian could pull off the same for a 14-hour game instead of a 22-minute show was never a sure thing. But there I was, shrunk down to Underpants Gnome-size, crawling up Mr. Slave’s orifices to retrieve a WMD, slicing through gobs of bodily fluids in turn-based JRPG combat and climbing up half-digested corn-on-the-cob as I went, laughing hysterically the whole way. I’m floored at how consistently funny it is, and at how well the outrageous comedy melds with the relatively simple gameplay to create not just an amazing South Park game, but an intelligent and witty satire of roleplaying mechanics.As for the story, it’s a clever premise that allows The Stick of Truth to take place in a recognizable and painstakingly recreated South Park setting, but also brings in all the usual fantasy roleplaying tropes through the power of children’s imagination. It’s a trick used many times in the show, and it works great for the game, too. An epic LARPing session (as casually set up by last year’s “Black Friday” trilogy of episodes) has your custom-created new kid in town joining either Cartman’s Humans or Kyle’s Elves, all dressed in amusingly bad makeshift cosplay outfits. True to the show, things escalate wildly and hilariously, leading to conspiracies involving the government, aliens, and Taco Bell.Though it manifests itself in typically over-the-top South Park-ian ways, The Stick of Truth is a Paper Mario-esque RPG-lite. You and your single extra party member (you’ll unlock several South Park regulars, though only one can fight with you at a time) take turns battling formations of enemies, be it the Gingers, crazy homeless guys, aliens, and more. Typical buffs and debuffs are ably skinned in screwed-up fourth grader verbiage (throwing feces to add “gross out” effects) mixed with mana-powered spells and timed button-press attacks and blocks to keep you on your toes during combat. It keeps things simple enough while still leaving room for some tactical depth. And Obsidian refreshingly leaves out time-sink annoyances like character encumbrance and random battles you can’t avoid.I couldn’t resist the curious lure of playing as the Jew class over the archetypal Fighter, Thief, and Mage options, but the differences between them turned out to be South Park: The Stick of Truth  March 4, 2014 Stan, Kenny, Kyle and Cartman set out to kick role-play gaming in the nuts with South Park: The Stick of Truth, an RPG set in the town of South Park.  →  Much More Ryan McCaffrey Says Try This Game If You Liked: South Park: Bigger, Longer and UncutSouth Park Let's Go Tower Defense Play!Paper Mario disappointingly slight. Sure, each has their own special abilities, but there are effectively no class-specific weapons or items, and there’s nothing to stop a Mage from choosing melee-enhancing gear and carving up foes with a blade just as well as a Fighter. All classes eventually learn special farting magic (a crude parody of Skyrim’s Dragon Shouts) though both the thumbstick motions and especially the tutorial sessions for your powers of flatulence tend to be cumbersome. Achievement or Trophy hunting aside, this lack of class differentiation or significant choices in the story are big reasons why I don’t feel much incentive to replay the campaign. The other unfortunate offense is that some extremely useful things are poorly explained, if they’re even mentioned at all. Tricks like being able to switch your Buddy at any time by pressing down on the D-pad to access the Party menu, or taking the first swing at overworld enemies so that you get the first turn when the battle starts, and what your Buddies can do and are specifically good at are all up to us to discover accidentally. One other puzzling issue is the slipperiness of the action-selection wheel during combat – it’s strangely difficult to get your pointer to stick on the option you want, particularly if it’s in a diagonal slot on the wheel.But that’s about the extent of the damage. Aesthetically, The Stick of Truth might be the most beautiful crappy-looking-on-purpose game I’ve ever seen. While it may seem trivial to make a role-playing game resemble the crude, construction-paper cutout style of the show, it’s executed so well here that the two mediums are almost indistinguishable. You’ll never see a HUD when walking around town, for instance, unless you tap the Y/Triangle button. Only the very rare stuck animation on an overworld enemy and (on both consoles, but not a capable PC) the occasional frame rate stutter when a new area loaded in for the first time reminded me that this was a game and not the show. And that was the extent of the technical problems I encountered.The VerdictThe Stick of Truth makes one thing abundantly clear: I never want to play another South Park video game made without Trey Parker and Matt Stone's direct,

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E14 South Park: The Stick of Truth 

			Views: 164		

			South Park: The Stick of Truth is a great love letter to fans. Its role-playing elements may be simple and easy but, if you enjoy the humor of South Park it will be more than enough to go through the...		

South Park: The Stick of Truth: It’s a very rare thing to see licenses from television shows or movies be made into a videogame and actually turn out to be a great game. South Park: The Stick of Truth is one of those rare occasions. A great role-playing game made by Obsidian Entertainment (creators of Fallout: New Vegas) along with the creators of South Park (who also do a lot of the voice acting) to create a funny and simple game in which to celebrate the world of South Park and also to give fans something to enjoy for years to come. While relatively short by most role-playing game standards, lasting between 15-18 hours, The Stick of Truth gives enough variety and plenty of humor to make it an easily enjoyable experience and worth the asking price. Everything in the game is wholly belonging to South Park, it has songs from episodes dotted throughout the game, voice actors make a return to voice their respective characters and everything feels like South Park. Visuals also feel directly translated from the show, the game feels like a very long episode of the show. Controls are simple and easy to learn, the game overall is pretty easy with only a few enemies posing a decent challenge so you won’t feel very much pressure from the combat portion of the game. The only real detriment to South Park: The Stick of Truth is the fact that it is everything South Park. While I personally find the game to be funny and enjoy the jokes, it is easy to see how this game can turn away those who aren’t huge fans or hate the humor that South Park has and there isn’t an amazing enough role-playing game here to win those on the fence about South Park over. The other minor gripe with the game is the controls when using the mouse and keyboards. Some of the abilities didn’t feel like they responded as well when using their respective keys versus a controller. I also experience a few glitches such as Jimmy not getting out of his stuttering loop and some minor glitches of my character flickering in and out of a scene during a cinematic. Overall I enjoyed my time with South Park: The Stick of Truth, there is a fun role-playing game here along with the great humor of South Park. Those who won’t enjoy this game are those who are going to be offended by what is displayed in the game or just don’t enjoy the humor of South Park. If you are middle of the ground and don’t mind the humor the role-playing game beneath may not be enough to warrant a full $60.00 USD price tag. -Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Review: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

And that was the extent of the technical problems I encountered.The VerdictThe Stick of Truth makes one thing abundantly clear: I never want to play another South Park video game made without Trey Parker and Matt Stone's direct,

												Fun game if you're a South Park fan. My only complaint is the fact that the storyline and game is VERY short. I picked up the game on sale and only played every couple of days for a few hours max, and beat the game in under 20 hours... And no, I didn't only complete the main story missions. I collected everything I could find and did tons of side quests for friends and just to extend the game. I belive the $30+ reguar price would be more justifed with some cheap DLC packs for extra missions (they wont make DLC for free...). Don't get me wrong, the voice acting and humor is exactly what you see on TV, this is basically a playable South Park episode. I just wish they added some more missions/quests to keep me coming back....TLDR; Get the game on sale. You can beat the entire game in under a day so try to limit yourself to a couple hours at a time to maximze playtime. If you are a South Park fan you will enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												First off, let me start by saying this game is FANTASTIC. I'm not a huge turn based RPG player, but I picked up the game with skepticism because I'd heard good things about it and it's South Park.The game is funny and engaging. It has a lot to do and I found myself spending entire afternoons and evenings playing this game (which I don't do very often). As I walked around South Park doing side quests I found myself laughing at the dialogue of people I passed by or my buddy when I did certain things or went certain places. There are so many Easter Eggs in this game that you can find while walking around looting (Butters' Creamy Goo and Chinpokomon to name a couple) and a lot of them are cleverly placed. South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic turn-based RPG and doesn't disappoint. The game feels like a very long episode of South Park and it actually looks like one too. I can recommend this to people who have only seen the show a few times and you'll still love it to death. 10/10.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												This is the greatest South Park game of all time. In its own right, this is a pretty great adventure/JRPG hybrid. Although every game mechanic has been used hundreds of times in every game, they've never been combined in such a way like this before. A JRPG with a full collect-a-thon system set in South Park, CO? That's a huge undertaking, and Obsidian have stepped up to the plate.The game is also relatively bug free, although its menus and interface look like♥♥♥♥♥ I have to assume that they did not have an interface designer, because the interface is both ugly and hard to use. Luckily, it's not too important, and beyond that the game is quite beautiful in its own South Park way.The biggest selling point of this game is the ability to play the game and have a hard time finding graphical inconsistencies that make it seem like you're not just watching an episode of South Park. This is a long, 15-hour episode of South Park, and it is pretty fantastic.However, do not buy the DLC. I picked them both up, and never used the equipment and items provided by the DLC.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												It’s really quite remarkable how South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone have slowly ramped up the shock value over the past 17 years to keep the show sharp. Whether they and developer Obsidian could pull off the same for a 14-hour game instead of a 22-minute show was never a sure thing. But there I was, shrunk down to Underpants Gnome-size, crawling up Mr. Slave’s orifices to retrieve a WMD, slicing through gobs of bodily fluids in turn-based JRPG combat and climbing up half-digested corn-on-the-cob as I went, laughing hysterically the whole way. I’m floored at how consistently funny it is, and at how well the outrageous comedy melds with the relatively simple gameplay to create not just an amazing South Park game, but an intelligent and witty satire of roleplaying mechanics.As for the story, it’s a clever premise that allows The Stick of Truth to take place in a recognizable and painstakingly recreated South Park setting, but also brings in all the usual fantasy roleplaying tropes through the power of children’s imagination. It’s a trick used many times in the show, and it works great for the game, too. An epic LARPing session (as casually set up by last year’s “Black Friday” trilogy of episodes) has your custom-created new kid in town joining either Cartman’s Humans or Kyle’s Elves, all dressed in amusingly bad makeshift cosplay outfits. True to the show, things escalate wildly and hilariously, leading to conspiracies involving the government, aliens, and Taco Bell.Though it manifests itself in typically over-the-top South Park-ian ways, The Stick of Truth is a Paper Mario-esque RPG-lite. You and your single extra party member (you’ll unlock several South Park regulars, though only one can fight with you at a time) take turns battling formations of enemies, be it the Gingers, crazy homeless guys, aliens, and more. Typical buffs and debuffs are ably skinned in screwed-up fourth grader verbiage (throwing feces to add “gross out” effects) mixed with mana-powered spells and timed button-press attacks and blocks to keep you on your toes during combat. It keeps things simple enough while still leaving room for some tactical depth. And Obsidian refreshingly leaves out time-sink annoyances like character encumbrance and random battles you can’t avoid.I couldn’t resist the curious lure of playing as the Jew class over the archetypal Fighter, Thief, and Mage options, but the differences between them turned out to be South Park: The Stick of Truth  March 4, 2014 Stan, Kenny, Kyle and Cartman set out to kick role-play gaming in the nuts with South Park: The Stick of Truth, an RPG set in the town of South Park.  →  Much More Ryan McCaffrey Says Try This Game If You Liked: South Park: Bigger, Longer and UncutSouth Park Let's Go Tower Defense Play!Paper Mario disappointingly slight. Sure, each has their own special abilities, but there are effectively no class-specific weapons or items, and there’s nothing to stop a Mage from choosing melee-enhancing gear and carving up foes with a blade just as well as a Fighter. All classes eventually learn special farting magic (a crude parody of Skyrim’s Dragon Shouts) though both the thumbstick motions and especially the tutorial sessions for your powers of flatulence tend to be cumbersome. Achievement or Trophy hunting aside, this lack of class differentiation or significant choices in the story are big reasons why I don’t feel much incentive to replay the campaign. The other unfortunate offense is that some extremely useful things are poorly explained, if they’re even mentioned at all. Tricks like being able to switch your Buddy at any time by pressing down on the D-pad to access the Party menu, or taking the first swing at overworld enemies so that you get the first turn when the battle starts, and what your Buddies can do and are specifically good at are all up to us to discover accidentally. One other puzzling issue is the slipperiness of the action-selection wheel during combat – it’s strangely difficult to get your pointer to stick on the option you want, particularly if it’s in a diagonal slot on the wheel.But that’s about the extent of the damage. Aesthetically, The Stick of Truth might be the most beautiful crappy-looking-on-purpose game I’ve ever seen. While it may seem trivial to make a role-playing game resemble the crude, construction-paper cutout style of the show, it’s executed so well here that the two mediums are almost indistinguishable. You’ll never see a HUD when walking around town, for instance, unless you tap the Y/Triangle button. Only the very rare stuck animation on an overworld enemy and (on both consoles, but not a capable PC) the occasional frame rate stutter when a new area loaded in for the first time reminded me that this was a game and not the show. And that was the extent of the technical problems I encountered.The VerdictThe Stick of Truth makes one thing abundantly clear: I never want to play another South Park video game made without Trey Parker and Matt Stone's direct,

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
 General Idea If you enjoy the show South Park, then you will enjoy this game! That being said, if you don't like the show, then you probably won't enjoy this game, as it is basically a 16 hour playable episode. Gameplay This game is absolutely hilarious! What you see in the TV show is pretty much what you can expect to see in this game. You can go into most buildings and houses.  In some houses that you try to enter, you will find people masturbating, people screwing horses, or naked dancing ladies.  You can raid people's houses of all their personal belongings and valuables, and nobody gives a damn. The only authority to you really is your parents,  and in one mission a hall monitor, but they don't really count.  There is a point at the beginning of the game when you realize that a fart is bound to the right mouse button. It is at that moment that you will realize what kind of game this is. You probably will love it from this moment on, as most players probably did. The missions are intriguing, and humor is scattered throughout the game everywhere. The one thing people may not like is the combat style. It is a turn-based combat sort of like the game Wizard101. This game is pretty much a single player RPG. You do missions and fight to get experience and level up. As you gain Facebook friends with the people throughout South Park, you will be able to upgrade your player.  Levels I will start by saying that the max level in this game is level 15. It is like many other RPGs, in that all items have a level requirement. I must say, in my opinion, that it takes a while to level up. In just about 9 hours of gameplay, I have only gotten to level 13. Based on this, it probably takes between 10-12 hours to get to level 15 and complete one of the classes. Campaign You start the campaign as the new kid who just moved to South Park, CO and the hope is that you will help the humans secure the Stick of Truth so that they can rule the universe. The war is between the Humans, led by Cartman, and the Elves, led by Kyle. There are 4 different classes you can choose to be, and they are:  Fighter, Mage, Thief,  and  Jew.   You are able to type a name in at the beginning of the game, but you are assigned the name "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" by Cartman.  The campaign is very fun and immersive, and you could easily find yourself sitting and playing this game for hours at a time. You will find out that it can be very hard to get up and stop playing this game. After you complete the campaign, however, there is nearly no drive to keep playing the game. Conclusion In my opinoin, every penny I put into this game has been worth it, because I purchased it when it was only $13.59. If you like South Park, and the game is on sale, do not pass it up! Since I don't watch the show very much because I never got into it, I actually only bought it because it was on sale. Once I installed it and played it I soon realized that it was a great purchase! While it is at its normal price of $40, it's really up to you whether or not you want to get it, but it is a fantastic game and you probably will come close to♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants because it is so funny. This game is definitely in my Top 5 favorites, and I completely recommend this game!Thank you for reading my review of South Park™: The Stick of Truth™

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												The video game of south park is everything you would expect it to be. You got the racism, the jew jokes, the poop humor and everything you have seen on TV. The game contains lots of items from previouse episodes and you are put into a well known universe (the south park universe that is). Just so it is said, even though it isn`t needed, if you don`t like South Park you won`t like this game. On the other hand if you like the series, you will love this game. It is true to the series. The main story is fun and it is one of the games I can play for hours without knowing how much time have passed, simply because I don`t care. I want to play forever. Character customization isn`t too good in this game, but it let you choose what you want to look like (you can even have plastick surgery to look like David Hasselhoff), you can also choose between 4 classes with different abilities, I would recommend the jew one. As for side quest; These are often quite easy and none of them are especially long, but they let you meet character from the series that you love, even mister hankey joins in at one point, if you can find him.The game is listed as an RPG but don`t take it for a full RPG as it only contains some of the aspects from that genre, stuff like open world, character customization and side quest (none of which are very deep). The play time is also a bit short for a RPG, between 10-15 hours.That said, the game is everything you would want form a South Park game and it is money well spent for you who enjoy the show.10/10

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E14 South Park: The Stick of Truth 

			Views: 164		

			South Park: The Stick of Truth is a great love letter to fans. Its role-playing elements may be simple and easy but, if you enjoy the humor of South Park it will be more than enough to go through the...		

South Park: The Stick of Truth: It’s a very rare thing to see licenses from television shows or movies be made into a videogame and actually turn out to be a great game. South Park: The Stick of Truth is one of those rare occasions. A great role-playing game made by Obsidian Entertainment (creators of Fallout: New Vegas) along with the creators of South Park (who also do a lot of the voice acting) to create a funny and simple game in which to celebrate the world of South Park and also to give fans something to enjoy for years to come. While relatively short by most role-playing game standards, lasting between 15-18 hours, The Stick of Truth gives enough variety and plenty of humor to make it an easily enjoyable experience and worth the asking price. Everything in the game is wholly belonging to South Park, it has songs from episodes dotted throughout the game, voice actors make a return to voice their respective characters and everything feels like South Park. Visuals also feel directly translated from the show, the game feels like a very long episode of the show. Controls are simple and easy to learn, the game overall is pretty easy with only a few enemies posing a decent challenge so you won’t feel very much pressure from the combat portion of the game. The only real detriment to South Park: The Stick of Truth is the fact that it is everything South Park. While I personally find the game to be funny and enjoy the jokes, it is easy to see how this game can turn away those who aren’t huge fans or hate the humor that South Park has and there isn’t an amazing enough role-playing game here to win those on the fence about South Park over. The other minor gripe with the game is the controls when using the mouse and keyboards. Some of the abilities didn’t feel like they responded as well when using their respective keys versus a controller. I also experience a few glitches such as Jimmy not getting out of his stuttering loop and some minor glitches of my character flickering in and out of a scene during a cinematic. Overall I enjoyed my time with South Park: The Stick of Truth, there is a fun role-playing game here along with the great humor of South Park. Those who won’t enjoy this game are those who are going to be offended by what is displayed in the game or just don’t enjoy the humor of South Park. If you are middle of the ground and don’t mind the humor the role-playing game beneath may not be enough to warrant a full $60.00 USD price tag. -Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Review: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Well, that was quite the adventure.  I almost don't know where to begin.Stick of Truth is a turn-based RPG, specifically more of the JRPG variety despite taking a few notes from the WRPG games.  But when I say turn-based, I don't mean that you simply click on the enemy you want to fight exactly one time and watch an attack happen.  This type of turn-based is much more interactive where you have to press certain buttons in a certain fashion for attacks to connect properly and deliver the most potential damage.  For example, when using Butter's Hammer of Storms ability, you have to click a button when the lightning strikes his hammer, or else the attack will fail and you'll perform a pitiful amount of damage to your target.  Then also, this same combat mechanic is used for blocking or quick time events, allowing you to either lessen the damage you receive or outright avoid it in certain situations.  It's very similar to the Mario RPGs in that regard, making it very interactive and forcing you to pay close attention.  Thanks to this, combat never really felt boring to me.The world of Stick of Truth is also extremely fun to explore.  I really did feel like the city of South Park was created to its fullest, giving me access to just about every location that was known in the show.  Most of the city is accessable right away for the most part, though there are a few places you can't reach until you unlock certain abilities.  But the game isn't harsh by allowing you to stay lost, for your menu will always tell you where you need to go and have a giant exclamation point over it on your map.  It even does the same thing for any side quests you're doing at the moment.  Now I know you might be worried about having to walk EVERYWHERE in this huge town to accomplish your many tasks, but thankfully, this game provides instant transport, reducing that monotomy.  It is such a huge time saver.The plot of the story, as you can probably guess, is pure comedy.  I mean, it's South Park, what do you expect?  As the story progresses, you'll find yourself laughing at just about everything in the game, whether it's for the ridiculous dirty humor or the jabs at the JRPG genre.  And yet, despite the humor, there really is a certain kind of epic feel to the story.  Yeah I know its just a bunch of fourth graders LARPing and blowing everything out of proportion, but I'm serious when I say I felt this game had some genuinely awesome moments.  Rescuing Princess Kenny from one of the elves that was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥her was one fine example.  Well pretending to♥♥♥♥♥♥her by jumping up and down on the bed with Kenny tied up next to him and just standing there (what you thought I was serious?). So to rescue her, you have to break into the bedroom, climb up some shelves, then rip the ceiling lamp dangling above the elf out so that the wiring is all loose so that it resembles a zipline.  Then you slide down the wire and with your momentum, ram right into the guy to knock him out and break the whole bed and get Kenny out.  It's so stupid and childish, but it was awesome at the same time.  And the music certainly helps give off that epic feel too.  The entire soundtrack sounds like something out of Skyrim or Lord of the Rings, which is just amazing and really helps add to the atmosphere of the whole thing.  With all that said, this game isn't for the sensitive.  Stick of Truth is merely South Park in video game format, meaning that the offensive and vulgar humor is still all there in its purest form.  And this time, absolutely nothing has to be censored (unless you're getting the European or Australlian version).  Some small spoilers here, but there is a part in the game where you have been shrunk down and there's a boss battle in your parent's bedroom on their bed.  While your parents are there.  Having sex while you are battling the boss underneath them.  With porno music playing the background.  Don't even get me started on the quick time event that occurs during the fight.  I feel bad for the poor suckers who played this in front of their sensitive friends/Twitch viewers and never saw it coming.  And only worse things happen, as hard as it is to believe.  But hey it's South Park.  I wouldn't expect anything less.  Especially since one of the achievements is even named "Too Far" and requires you to do something really messed up.  This was Trey Parker and Matt Stone's first attempt at becoming involved in a South Park video game.  There were previous South Park games, but none of them had Trey and Matt actively working alongside the development team.  And boy, can you tell that those two had put everything into this game.  I couldn't even begin to name all of the references to the show that they put in here.  It's simply impossible.  This game, is without a doubt, one of the most entertaining and hilarious games I've played in a very long time and I applaud those two for all of the effort they put into it.  Despite it being only about 10-20 hours long, kind of easy at times, and awkward to watch other times, they did a fantastic job.Here's looking forward to the Fractured But Whole.And whatever you do, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT HEADPHONES.  It is extremely NSFW and your parents will probably disown if they see you doing even half of the stuff in the game.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This game is fantastic! If you are a fan of the South Park show then you'll love it. It's different from any other TV/Movie turned game that I've ever played in the way that this one is actually worth playing. Not only is it funny, but it's fun. The game mechanics, while a bit dated, work well. The artwork/graphics were done perfectly. The voices are perfect. Above all else though the game it's self is good. There is no poor, glossed over, rushed feel to this game, it doesn't have that lack luster, "I'm trying to just milk this franchise for everything it's worth" feel. Not being bad isn't enough though to make it good. What makes it good is not only the glitch free game play, but that the game play it's self is fun. There are four different classes and each plays differently. You can choose different sides while playing the game and there are plenty of side missions to keep you busy as well. Some offer up new gear, while others help you unlock more perks. This game follows the South Park tradition of being raunchy and some times just plain wrong... Only you are dealing with more than just a cut scene, you are playing through it. I laughed my a$$ off the first time I played it and still had some laughs the second time though. I don't want to spoil the story for anyone who has yet to play though it, and I was careful about that in my screen shots. If you have been thinking about picking this up, go for it. You don't even have to wait for a sale for it to be worth it. I have some screen shots posted as well without any spoilers so feel free to check them out.Two very big thumbs up for South Park fans!

												Stick of truth is the funniest, most disgusting and entraining games I've played. The game recreates the show perfectly, the voice acting is amazing, the script is the funniest and most disgusting of all the south park stuff I've seen (saw until season 13 I think).Even if I prefer real-time combat (big fan of hack-n-slash games and shooters) this combat felt great because the attacks and armor the enemies wore was so ridiculous, I hate turn based RPGs but I like this type of game where you get damage boost or can avoid some damage by clicking/pressing a button at the right time (Paper Mario was my favourite RPG before this one). But in it could have been a little bit harder, I had no problems except for one optional boss battle (I'm super cereal) and I didn't felt the necesity to change partner except for the part where you had to, I only changed them for the lulz but the first partner felt like it was the best.The story is hilarious, there wasn't a 10 minutes period where I didn't at least giggle. The only thing that annoyed me is that most characters acted like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥to me x3 but is South Park.. so... and there were a lot of things I wish were included in the game but I'm hoping the sequel has them. And I hated the junk stuff was really good and packed with references, I didn't wanted to sell anything haha. Loved that the chinpokomon were collectibles (one of my favorite episodes).It had problems, the combat felt a little too easy and repetitive by the end (but not much) but in the end it was a total plessure to play it and it was the first game that made me actually laugh out loud through out the whole game. I rate it 9/10.SPOILER!!I'm a sick ♥♥♥♥ and loved the Mr. Slave♥♥♥♥♥♥level and the gnomes part xD (it was as awkward as funny).

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Ubisoft titles on PC do not have a good reputation. Because of that I approached this game with trepidation. I am glad to say that it doesn't require that god awful Uplay. The game itself is what you would expect of South Park. The game feels as though you are seeing/playing an actual episode of the titular show. Your favorite characters are here including Cartman, Butters, Tweek, Jimmy, Craig, Kenny and more. You start by creating your very own character who is a bit of a blank slate. In true South Park fashion Cartman starts the mud slinging as soon as you give your character a name. Its from this moment that you nod your head knowingly that this is indeed South Park. You are on a quest to protect the stick of truth and keep it from the hands of the elves. Along the way you will meet meth addicts, aliens and more. Its hard to write a review without spoiling some of the great moments in the game that will put a smile on your face. Beneath its crass, crude and faithful exterior is a surprising amount of depth in the gameplay itself. You have magic, ranged and melee attacks and find various bits of gear to equip. You have abilities that use PP while others like your fart attacks use mana. The game makes clever use of allowing you to time a counter and block incoming damage. One of my favorite abilities is kicking enemies in the nuts to stun them. Completing sidequests can also net you some powerful summons that you can use as well. In the end Stick of Truth is not only one of the more faithful licensed games I have played. But it may just be one of the best licensed games I have played. If you are a fan of South Park you are sure to enjoy this adventure. Pick it up on sale now or preorder the sequel and get this one for free.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Use your potions.  Liker seriously, every turn until your down to cleaning up the last guy.  Most rpg's you never use potions cause you never need them, and you want to save them for a boss battle and end up never needing them there either.  Maybe theyre expensive or hard to find in most rpgs.  Not in South Park.  You get a ton of every kind of potion for free everywhere.  You can use them every turn, and never buy one, and you'll never run out.  So really, feel free to use them early and often.  Not using the potions can actually make even some trash battles very difficult.Game is great.  If you like the show, you'll like the storyline.  Tons of inside jokes and references to old episodes.  All the 'junk' that you accumulate (which btw you can freely sell, there is no crafting or any use for it whatsoever) is stuff mentioned in the episodes.Tons of cameos from minor or incidental characters (underpants gnomes, lemmiwinks, etc).Battle system takes a bit of getting used to.  It's not purely a turn based rpg, there are some twitch elements to doing every action.  But you get used to it and can just avoid any actions that you have trouble with and use others instead.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ Review (A Fan Review, won't pay compliments nor shortens)South Park is a popular show, started in 1997 and been processing episodes, seasons until now. they have finished 17 seasons. finally, Trey Parker and Matt Stone decided to create a hands on South Park project, they have said: "We Wanted The South Park Game To Be More/Better Than The Show", Whether they'll succeed in making it, whether they will fail a big failture, Whether South Park fans will leave watching South Park because of the South Park Game. The question is: "Does South Park: The Stick of Truth Deserve To Be a Great Game"...?   


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick of Truth - E3 2012 Announcement 

			Views: 53,348		

			Trey Parker and Matt Stone take the E3 stage to talk about their new RPG, South Park: The Stick of Truth.		

PresentationSouth Park: The Stick of Truth brought a wondeful experience at almost every hand. Obsidian Entertainment have done a better than Fallout: New Vegas game. South Park: The Stick of Truth delievers the show and more, brought one of the most abrupt stories I've seen so far in "Years", although the story has a weak reputation but has one of the very unexpected moments that you totally....will "never" expect it from the very beginning to the very ending. If you loved the complex story moments of BioShock: Infinite, so there is no reason that you'll never like South Park: The Stick of Truth's unexpected story turning points.


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick of Truth Destiny Trailer 

			Views: 163,864		

			Ready the anal probe!		

 GameplaySouth Park: The Stick of Truth is a 2D, Adventure, Comedy, Action, Role-Playing Game and animation game. but I can say a "RPG" game. The Combat System is basically not that difficult to win, It's "One hit from my side, then One hit from your side" (Not always "One hit", depends in, how many your partners fighting in the battle, right now. in a better way, the quantity of your partners and the quantity of your enemies). the combat system doesn't depend in, how skillful you are, it depends in, how good is your weapon. when you attack an enemy by a hit, your attack causes to him damage, maybe...543, 4694....the stronger the weapon, the tougher, faster you are in a battle.


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick Of Truth - Combat System 

			Views: 202		

			South Park: The Stick of Truth gameplay recorded from Xbox 360 Version on a Hauppage HD Rocket PVR. Video shows the combat system of the game from the very start of the story.		

The WorldWell....almost all RPG games have a map, to explore, dig it deeply, kill enemies, start finish every side mission. South Park: The Stick of Truths' map is the same of South Park the show. Intersted in the world of the South Park show? so this is 95% similar to the show's world. the world is brilliantly fascinating. 												South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ Review (A Fan Review, won't pay compliments nor shortens)South Park is a popular show, started in 1997 and been processing episodes, seasons until now. they have finished 17 seasons. finally, Trey Parker and Matt Stone decided to create a hands on South Park project, they have said: "We Wanted The South Park Game To Be More/Better Than The Show", Whether they'll succeed in making it, whether they will fail a big failture, Whether South Park fans will leave watching South Park because of the South Park Game. The question is: "Does South Park: The Stick of Truth Deserve To Be a Great Game"...?   


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick of Truth - E3 2012 Announcement 

			Views: 53,348		

			Trey Parker and Matt Stone take the E3 stage to talk about their new RPG, South Park: The Stick of Truth.		

PresentationSouth Park: The Stick of Truth brought a wondeful experience at almost every hand. Obsidian Entertainment have done a better than Fallout: New Vegas game. South Park: The Stick of Truth delievers the show and more, brought one of the most abrupt stories I've seen so far in "Years", although the story has a weak reputation but has one of the very unexpected moments that you totally....will "never" expect it from the very beginning to the very ending. If you loved the complex story moments of BioShock: Infinite, so there is no reason that you'll never like South Park: The Stick of Truth's unexpected story turning points.


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick of Truth Destiny Trailer 

			Views: 163,864		

			Ready the anal probe!		

 GameplaySouth Park: The Stick of Truth is a 2D, Adventure, Comedy, Action, Role-Playing Game and animation game. but I can say a "RPG" game. The Combat System is basically not that difficult to win, It's "One hit from my side, then One hit from your side" (Not always "One hit", depends in, how many your partners fighting in the battle, right now. in a better way, the quantity of your partners and the quantity of your enemies). the combat system doesn't depend in, how skillful you are, it depends in, how good is your weapon. when you attack an enemy by a hit, your attack causes to him damage, maybe...543, 4694....the stronger the weapon, the tougher, faster you are in a battle.


YouTube™ Video: South Park: The Stick Of Truth - Combat System 

			Views: 202		

			South Park: The Stick of Truth gameplay recorded from Xbox 360 Version on a Hauppage HD Rocket PVR. Video shows the combat system of the game from the very start of the story.		

The WorldWell....almost all RPG games have a map, to explore, dig it deeply, kill enemies, start finish every side mission. South Park: The Stick of Truths' map is the same of South Park the show. Intersted in the world of the South Park show? so this is 95% similar to the show's world. the world is brilliantly fascinating. I can say it, "Better than Grand Theft Auto V's world (Although I gave Grand Theft Auto V a 10 out of 10 in my review)" not only Grand Theft Auto but also can be often "developed" as the best world of a game in history. your question is, "why and how can you infer it as a better world", the answer of the question will never can be explained by speaking, convincing, visualising pretty hard, it just can't be. but in short: an alive world, funny people, lack of empty spots.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xl8iw7N5JtoCanadaSouth Park: The Stick of Truth has two worlds, not only the world South Park is found but also Canada is found. Canada is pretty, pretty and pretty fun place to go and have the funniest citizen. South Park: The Stick of Truth's Canada is a 2D or a 3D style (There is no 3D in South Park: The Stick of Truth), but it's a nintendo's old devices games style (8 bit style). there are bears, snakes and wolf to fight which South Park doesn't have. South Park: The Stick of Truth's Canada contains its own music, sounds effects.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BbuVtz7aqnACharactersCartman is too funny at the point that doesn't get silly anymore. Butter is stupid at a point that meets its gloriously character. Kyle is annoying and hated by Cartman and the New Kid (Doughtbag), but after that you'll start changing your opinion about him. Stan is the same as Kyle. Princess Kenny is indescribable. ManBearPig makes the stupidest conflicts on earth Randy is the best character of all time who loves Taco Bell. there are so much more.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XH9dDkQ_tlIThe VerdictA must-own game, contains, one of the very best funniest characters, settings, story. I couldn't see better characters than South Park: The Stick of Truths' (Couldn't). South Park: The Stick of Truth is one of the best games in "Years" plus the "best" beginning in "Years". South Park: The Stick of Truth is more/better than South Park the show. South Park: The Stick of Truth is yet the best game of 2014, and deserves to be nominated for Game of The Year 2014. If you wanna play a fascinating 15 hours game, so your choice is South Park: The Stick of Truth. Won't forget: from the same developers of Fallout: New Vegas and Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II. Definitely, South Park: The Stick of Truth is a MUST-OWN game. Trust me, MUST OWN, BUT IT, RIGHT NOW.Story: 10/10Gameplay: 10/10Graphics: 9.5/10Sounds: 9.5/10Music: 10/10+ Positives+Wonderful World+Funny+Story is unpredictable+Soft Combat System+Over-Prefect Characters+Doesn't Seem Hard Nor Easy+More Than The Show+Enemies Are Amazing+Perfect Design In Each Hand+Is fun- Negatives-Small Size World Compared to "RPG" Game-Lack Explorations of Powerful WeaponsObsidian Entertainment showed us how good they are. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												South Park is a tough game to review. From a game mechanic standpoint it doesn't break any new ground. Gameplay is thin, the controls (to fart) are annoying and it's relatively short (15 hours) for what it costs.If this were any other RPG, it would be widely condemned. But it's South Park through and through, which means you'll both laugh and cringe at the same time. What other game will have you fighting an underpants gnome while trying to dodge a giant ball sack? What game has you crawling through someone's rear end while a gerbil sings to you? Occasionally side-splitting, often head-shaking, the humor in Stick of Truth is exactly like the show. That's really what you're playing and paying for here. You're interacting with a 15 hour episode of South Park, lovingly nurtured, written and voice acted by Matt and Trey. The RPG mechanics are just an excuse to call it a game. You're playing this because it's just like watching a season of the show. You're going to visit all of the areas you know and love from the series. You're going to the Mongorian grill. You're going to meet up with Jesus. You're going to the wrong side of the tracks to Kenny's House. And you're going to do this as the "New Kid" that fits in perfectly with the rest of the cast of characters for a wild, weird and wonderful time.If that doesn't sound like it's funny then this game isn't for you. If you find the show rude, crude and reprehensible, then you should run (not walk)away. But if you like the show, if you like the humor, wit, crudeness and everything else that goes on in South Park then you'll enjoy this game as I did. If you don't, well...respect my authoritah!

South Park: The Stick of Truth has the ability to beat 2014's games and pretend itself as a nominee for Game of The Year 2014. That's not impossible.9.2/10 Amazinghttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7u3AyqgqbHw (Warning, Contains Many Spoilers)Recommended Price: 49.99$Games Are Similar To It:Family Guy The Video Game (In Maps Design)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I've always liked South Park, and this review is probably gonna be a little biased by that. I can say straight away, if you don't like the series, then don't get this game, and stop reading.I was a little worried about what to expect with this game when I saw the first gameplay videos. A mix of adventure and turnbased combat is a very rare thing to see these days, atleast among the "larger" titles. As soon as the game or rather episode started, my worries disappeared. This is not so much a game,as it is another episode in South Park.You take on the role as the new kid in town, and as you get forced to make friends in the neighbourhood, all sorts of crazy adventures and humorous catastrophes happen. The story is very good and the progression in this, has never been to slow or to fast. I find that in some games the story gets lost in to much gameplay or the gameplay gets ruined by the story. This game seems to keep the balance between gameplay and story very nicely, which I find is very important to a game with so much comedy. This leads me to the main reason to get the game. The amount of profanity, insanity and sexuality mixed in with a nice amount of violence left me laughing out loud more times I can remember. If you like South Park humour the game is certainly required in your game collection.The gameplay is nothing elaborate or even diffecult. You wander around on maps, interacting with items, people or enemies, and move between these maps without any load time. When you encounter an enemy, the game switches to a turnbased combat phase. The combat is fairly straightforward and for each attack there is a combination of mouseclicking and button-mashing to get it to work. Even if you fail in this sorta easy mash-click-buttoning (Which I did plenty of times), you will still damage your enemy, albeit for a smaller amount of damage. The combat sorta has a tactical element with selecting the right attack for the correct enemy and at the same time requiring a bit of skill with that click-button-mashing. The same applies to the enemy attacks, which you can defend yourself from.The graphics and sound are the same as in the series, though there was a part in the game that changed considerably. I wont spoil anything in this review, but I can tell that I liked the retro-feel of it, and in combination with the story it was a little detail that left me smiling and laughing.The game in itself would be 5 out of 5 stars from me. This however leaving out the price of the game and also the replay value. There are some small elements of choice in the game, but none that will make the story change to much. There are some choices with your class, and some choices during the game, none of which really makes that much of an impact on the story, which is my main reason to get the game. I spent 22 hours playing the game and with a price of 40 euros, that is a big price to pay for a game with nearly no replay value. Still, I look at this game as a gem, and 22 hours laughing and smiling, well... I pay around 10 euros to go to the movies, and those only last what? Like 2 hours?

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
TL;DR at BottomIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!7/10Hesitant Recommendation


Come on down to South Park 
A Screenshot of South Park™: The Stick of Truth™
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




South Park: The Stick of Truth is a South Park themed RPG created by Obsidian and published by Ubisoft. Now don't let Ubisoft's name put you off because even though South Park is an Ubisoft game you don't need Uplay to play it. The game is about 10 hours in length even with side quests and most of the time you'll be completing the 10 or twelve story missions the game has to offer. The game is locked to 30 frames per second although due to the aesthetic it actually works in this specific case. The game as a whole is very well put together but since most of South Park is dependent on very subjective themes like humor, reception will vary wildy from person to person.


Taco Bell 
A Screenshot of South Park™: The Stick of Truth™
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




South Park takes place in, you guessed it, the small town of South Park and you play as a nameless and voiceless new kid on the block. You soon meet with Cartman and Butters and discover the fantasy world that these kids have set up, joining them in the process. This game that the kids play revolves around a "magical" item called the stick of truth and whoever controls said stick can then control the universe. Over the course of the game you run all across South Park gathering support for the humans so that you can assault the elves and take back the stick. Most of the story is just lots of general outlines of what could have been a funny story but instead was stuffed with toilet humor and fan service. A large amount of the lines end up being incredibly cringe-worthy, such as the overarching theme that you should never fart on someone's balls or some of the lines the girls have. The entire story ends up being mostly running around South Park and trying to recruit the various factions to play with you (I.E. The Goths and the girls). None of the characters are anything close to interesting and for a game that calls itself an RPG they really don't explain much about the characters and instead seem to rely on you having watched the show. As most of the characters are dull and repetitive, so too are the environments and in South Park you'll be running back and forth throughout the same environments over and over again for some tedious quest or another and in the end this is just too mind-numbingly boring.


Kupa Keep 
A Screenshot of South Park™: The Stick of Truth™
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




The gameplay, however, is actually pretty well done as far as most RPG's go. You have multiple different methods of attacks: Ranged, melee, magic and abilities along with a plethora of consumables for mid-battle use. You acquire many different kinds of weapons and armor over the course of the story and each piece has its own bonuses that come with it. Most of the armor bonuses are just passive bonuses and thus are pretty boring but there really wasn't much else they could've done with this so I can let it slide. The armor types and models are suprisingly varied and you can get some pretty cool looking sets that really feel like something you would see kids create. You can customize your armor to a degree with various slottable upgrades and different colored dyes but for the most part the main bits of the armor cannot be changed. If you have half a mind and explore even the slightest bit then South Park will prove to be incredibly easy and, as far as RPG's go, incredibly short, as the game should clock in at about 10 hours and that's counting about two hours of exploring that I did early on. South Park has a real problem with difficulty and for pretty much the entire game, with the exception of a fight or two, it's incredibly easy. South Park has a very limited setting to work with and as such seeing the same old parts of the town can really hit you with a feeling of tedium that an RPG cannot have. Most of the side quests are pretty boring too and really end up being either fetch quests or quests you can't finish until later so you forget about them. Since The Stick of Truth is an RPG you can upgrade your character with various perks ability upgrades. Ability upgrades follow a linear upgrade line while perks can be unlocked in any order but also tend to have a more minor impact on gameplay. You unlock perks by getting more friends which you unlock by simply talking to people or doing their quests and it does give the town of South Park a very connected feel as if everybody knows everybody. There's also the buddy system where you can take one buddy along with you to fight in combat and help you out with environmental roadblocks. The buddies are simply a letdown because you end up unlocking the final one not halfway into the game and you are never given any reason to switch off of the first buddy given to you. TL;DRAn RPG with solid gameplay that's severely hampered by places of cringe-worthy dialogue and overuse of toilet humor. Only for fans of the series.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												South Park: The Stick of Truth is a faithful to the show rpg-lite adventure into the life of the new kid. You can expect all the vulgarity and over the top situations that are in the show along with various nods to the show itself like songs such as "love gravy" and "i've got something in my front pocket for you".Many a number of the main characters make appearences in the game with the most recognizable being available as buddies that fight alongside you. Butters is the first of such allies and features a special attack where he transforms into Professor Chaos.The game also features four classes. Mage, fighter, thief and Jew. All with their unique abilities such as the Jew classes "sling of david"The game is a short outing with available sidequests, you can expect a playtime without dong any side quests to be around12-14 hours. Definately quite short for the genre, though I wouldn't consider it a full fledged rpg. The game provides excellent fan service and a true to the show animation and visual presentation.Highly recommended for die-hard fans of the show.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This is probably the best South Park game one could hope for, and it's one of the best and most fulfilling games I've played in recent years.For one, the sidequests don't feel tacked-on.They're an integral part of the whole, and they're actually worth doing in order to receive some more hilarious rewards.The combat is simple, but it does feel as rewarding as in any other turn-based RPG to see the high numbers fly.The length of the game is perfect.It took me about 16 hours of gameplay in order to wrap up all of the collectables, sidequests, and main story missions.On top of all of this, it looks and sounds amazing as well.Definite must-own for the South Park fan, and potential gateway drug for the fan-recruit.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I've always liked South Park, and this review is probably gonna be a little biased by that. I can say straight away, if you don't like the series, then don't get this game, and stop reading.I was a little worried about what to expect with this game when I saw the first gameplay videos. A mix of adventure and turnbased combat is a very rare thing to see these days, atleast among the "larger" titles. As soon as the game or rather episode started, my worries disappeared. This is not so much a game,as it is another episode in South Park.You take on the role as the new kid in town, and as you get forced to make friends in the neighbourhood, all sorts of crazy adventures and humorous catastrophes happen. The story is very good and the progression in this, has never been to slow or to fast. I find that in some games the story gets lost in to much gameplay or the gameplay gets ruined by the story. This game seems to keep the balance between gameplay and story very nicely, which I find is very important to a game with so much comedy. This leads me to the main reason to get the game. The amount of profanity, insanity and sexuality mixed in with a nice amount of violence left me laughing out loud more times I can remember. If you like South Park humour the game is certainly required in your game collection.The gameplay is nothing elaborate or even diffecult. You wander around on maps, interacting with items, people or enemies, and move between these maps without any load time. When you encounter an enemy, the game switches to a turnbased combat phase. The combat is fairly straightforward and for each attack there is a combination of mouseclicking and button-mashing to get it to work. Even if you fail in this sorta easy mash-click-buttoning (Which I did plenty of times), you will still damage your enemy, albeit for a smaller amount of damage. The combat sorta has a tactical element with selecting the right attack for the correct enemy and at the same time requiring a bit of skill with that click-button-mashing. The same applies to the enemy attacks, which you can defend yourself from.The graphics and sound are the same as in the series, though there was a part in the game that changed considerably. I wont spoil anything in this review, but I can tell that I liked the retro-feel of it, and in combination with the story it was a little detail that left me smiling and laughing.The game in itself would be 5 out of 5 stars from me. This however leaving out the price of the game and also the replay value. There are some small elements of choice in the game, but none that will make the story change to much. There are some choices with your class, and some choices during the game, none of which really makes that much of an impact on the story, which is my main reason to get the game. I spent 22 hours playing the game and with a price of 40 euros, that is a big price to pay for a game with nearly no replay value. Still, I look at this game as a gem, and 22 hours laughing and smiling, well... I pay around 10 euros to go to the movies, and those only last what? Like 2 hours?

												There is a lot to be enjoyed in this game, even more so for a die hard fan of South Park, but the game has a solid play style, lots of content to be enjoyed over roughly 10-20 hours worth of gameplay with a whole lot of laughs to ensue. It's a classic turn based RPG mixed with the TV show South Park so if you're a fan of either (or both) you will want to give this game a go.For my full in depth review, go to:http://godbomb.blogspot.co.uk/2014/04/south-park-stick-of-truth-review-for-pc.html

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												I don't generally like South Park's sense of humor as a television show.  Shock humor doesn't tend to offend me, I just usually don't find it that funny.  Moreover, Trey and Matt's middle finger to the world, everything is equally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t" social and political commentary can be grating; it is both intellectually shallow and safe.  Having said that, South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic game.  It's like a raunchy Earthbound with Super Mario RPG style timed battle mechanics.  The world of modern day kids playing make believe fantasy is fantastic setting for an RPG and feels really fresh. You really never really know where the game will take you next. And the game mines alot of RPG and videogame tropes for some pretty funny humor.  It doesn't waste your time will filler content; it's a tightly edited, sleek 12-14 hour package.  Some of the attempts at humor may make you roll your eyes a bit, but Stick of Truth is a game regardless.  But perhaps most surprising, despite the abuse and ridicule it sometimes dishes out to it's characters, it is clearly game that has a lot of heart and views its characters endearingly.  It's Charlie Brown for a more cynical era combined with a well crafted RPG. Recommended.

Also South park was recreated in incredible detail, and everything will instantly feel familiar.For the fans of the show: It's a must have! Absolutely. For those who don't like the show, you should stay away of this game. Because anything you don't like about the show, you will find it in here.I had an awesome time, and I am very glad that I picked this one up.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												+ Constantly humorous+ Interesting (but small) world to explore+ Fan service for South Park fans+ Good length considering the source material- Simplistic, unchallenging combat- Spotty save system     South Park fans rejoice! This game is fanservice at its best. As an unabashed South Park fan, this game had me literally laughing out loud for most of the game. If you are a South Park fan, do not hesitate to buy The Stick of Truth! If you're not, I'm afraid that the RPG-style gameplay may be a bit dull and a bit too easy to keep you interested. You'll find yourself spamming the same couple of attacks in every battle. The timed button presses make it a bit more engaging, but once you're doing them by muscle memory... battle kinda becomes a chore.      There are a fair amount of collectable elements that make exploring all the nooks and crannies of the seemingly shrunken town of South Park more interesting, at least on the first playthough. Absolutely no grinding, very few fetch quests, and the game doesn't draw anything out unneccisarily, making it short but sweet. It's sort of like an RPG for people who don't play RPG's, but honestly the gameplay is just there to add a 'game' element to what is otherwise a long episode of South Park.     Be wary of the autosave system! Reloading a game may mean you have to go back and re-do something because it doesn't save your exact moment of progress! Pay attention each time you load your game, as there are some missable collectables! I missed out on a major achievement because of this wonky system. TALK TO CLYDE AS SOON AS YOU ENTER KUPA KEEP! You'll thank me later!89/100Funny and fun, South Park fans should definitely play this! This RPG-stlye game is simple, but doesn't drag you through hours of pointless distractions.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ is one of the few TV series based games out there that totally excels at both storytelling and gameplay. It feels like a 15 hour long (well, a little less for you if you don't do sidequests, level up or just walk around) episode.It has everything you can expect from South Park and more. It parodies almost all RPG games ever created in such an hilarious way, because remember, it IS South Park after all.Having explicit +18 content like it should, the PC version doesn't have any censorship which is great because censoring South Park is missing the point of it. Also, it borders the riddiculous so many times it's amazing how they managed to put this whole story together while keeping its humour fresh.On the technical side, a few bugs and glitches here and there that hopefully will be fixed with later patches. Nothing too serious, only a few character flickers in the cinematics and sometimes the music won't play, but nothing that breaks the game in any way (maybe some of the immersion, but that being said, reloading the last checkpoint usually helped).Now, to the most important part on where you should or not buy the game: IS IT WORTH THE $60 PRICETAG? No. Not at all. I expect playing it only once more right now and maybe replaying it at a later date ocassionally just for the laughs. No multiplayer because remember this is a turn based RPG and we wouldn't have it any other way, but that removes a lot from the replayability value and thus the pricetag should be lower. 30 bucks is about right, 1.50 an hour. Maybe even less, like 15 bucks.But that shouldn't stop me from recommending this anyway. Because this game is awesome. It feels like a game. It IS a game. And also a 15 hour long South Park episode. And both are worth the time and the cash to enjoy.I hope they release some DLC with an expansion on the story or something because it still has room for more content.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Alright 5 hours into the game (including time wasted between laughter, exploration, and being outright stuck), it's been pretty reminiscent as well as enjoyful. A lot of references, and definitely the humor most people recognize the series as being known for.Pros:- Customization (character, appearance, stats, abilities)- Interactivity (Really does feel like an RPG game, in both fights and exploration of the overworld.)- The same stupid (but laughable) comedy this series has been known for.Cons:- Known bugs that can interrupt your playthrough (Experienced one such bug when learning my first Magic spell. I had to reload a checkpoint about 1 minute before the tutorial).- Instructions can sometimes be unclear of where to go next, or interactable items can be difficult to notice (This may not apply to all people. I was stuck twice for about 10 minutes each unsure of what to do next.).- Even for the humor and gameplay (Let's be serious, this was not a game for a high graphics expectation), compared to other games available now at similar or lower prices, I say it is not worth the FULL $60. It's worth a good chunk of that in my opinion (Like $30-$40), but not the full $60.Overall: Worth getting if you see it on sale. It's a good time filler when I want to play a game on my own, that a 3-year old laptop can still run at perfect frames.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												South Park: The Stick of Truth is a role-playing adventure game.The game starts with the mute protagonist being ordered to leave the house and make friends in his new home town of South Park. Immediately you become a friend of Butters and he gets you into the Human clan of a Dungeon & Dragons-esque group ruled by the Grand Wizard Cartman. You are given the choice between four character classes. You can be a Fighter, a Mage, a Thief, or a Jew.At the first part of South Park: The Stick of Truth you spend your time recruiting factions and battling elves to reclaim the stick. In true South Park fashion the story escalates out of control leading to being abducted by aliens, shrank by underpants gnomes and travelling to 8-bit Canada to translate abortion documents written in French. The story makes sense in the context of South Park and it was genuinely a lot of fun to play through.Between collecting Chinpokomon, completing all the side quests and levelling up this game will take up close to 20 hours to complete.The game looks exactly like the show.The voice acting is very good, all known voices from the television show are there. The music is also very good. Besides of epic middle-earth music playing in the town, you can listen to songs from the television show in stores.Overall South Park: The Stick of Truth is absolutely epic! It literally feels like the show. If you are a fan of South Park you will love it.Sounds 10/10Graphics 10/10Gameplay 9/10Atmosphere 10/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I'm going to go ahead and give my rating and then explain why I gave it such. South Park: The Stick of Truth, in my opinion, gets a 9/10. Now, you start off the game by creating your character. The amount of different customization combinations is actually pretty impressive. There are plenty of hairstyles, makeup, facial features and much more when you actually get into the game so I felt like my character was unique. I'll go ahead and compare it to Skyrim's character creation. Now, I'm not talking about all of the different things you can tweak on your character. I'm talking about the way you can make a character that is yours and yours only. I've yet to actually see someone else that has any characters looking similar to mine.Alright then, now let's get onto the rest of the game since talking about cool character creation woulnd't be much of a review. I enjoyed the story very much. It was exactly of the quality you would expect from an episode of South Park. In fact, the whole game made me feel as if I was in the show because of how immersed I was in it. It was funny, weird, disgusting, racist and the many other terms that South Park is famous for. They even reference some old episodes in the game, whether by dialogue or abilities or even some items you see while exploring the town. There's a very good variety of side quests that you can do if you don't want to just breeze through the main one. The combat system is also well-done. They do their own take on a turn-based battle sytem that I thought was pretty refreshing since I haven't played one of those in a while since Pokemon Y. What is even better is that their are so many things that can happen in combat that it actually makes you strategize so that you can win the battle. Your character can Bleed, Slow, become Grossed Out, set on Fire, and Dazed. Not sure if that's all of them either. And then their are things that do that opposite and increase either Attack, Defense, give you Shields, or restore your PP so that you can use another ability. There are also a TON of weapons that you can use for combat. You either buy them, find them, or are given them at any time during the game. Each weapon comes with their own unique stat boosts or perks that can help you dominate a battle. Then you can even add more boosts onto them via Stickers, each either increasing the different types of damage you decide to do, increasing your health, gives you armor so that you basically become a tank if you have enough stacked on you, or even heal you after landing a perfect attack or blocking one. Needless to say, you won't be short on the different types of weapons that you can have and kick all of the other kids asses, whether it be with a sword or a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oh, and the same goes with the armor. Plenty of them to put on your character and they can also have Stickers be put on them as well. I like to talk about graphics but I kind of don't really see the point since... it's South Park. Not exactly supposed to be graphically oriented. I was happy with getting to walk around the town by having my character haphazerdly hop with each step everywhere he went. Another cool thing is that you get to have a companion with you, both in and out of fights. The first one you start off with is Butters. He goes around with you, talking about where you are or what you're supposed to be doing for the main mission in the game, plus all of his own unique dialogue. The rest of the companions do the same as well and none of them sound like each other. No one says the same sentence another companion would and I really liked that. I'm going to go ahead and wrap this up by saying that you will completely enjoy the main storyline in the game. It's about 12 hours long but they're going to be a DAMN good 12 hours. I was laughing and enjoying myself during the entire game and the ending was satisfying to me. Sure, the humor is crude but I've always loved that about South Park so I didn't mind it at all. The only reason I didn't give this game a perfect score was because I had some performance issues at one point in the game. Don't know if it was because of my system or not but it just bothered me a bit. Other than that, it's a great game and deserves the sixty bucks you'll not have if you buy it.

Posted: March 19, 2014
												While inside a gay man's♥♥♥♥♥ i summoned the gay man inside his own♥♥♥♥♥to shove another guy up that♥♥♥♥♥for an instant kill and got an achievement. 10/10In all seriousness though, South Park, the stick of truth, is EXACTLY what it should be. It's rude, disgusting, foul mouthed, and frankly pretty offensive, and that's AWESOME. It entierly captures the spirit of South Park into a video game, making you feel like you're actually playing through an episode of the series, a hard goal for most video game adaptations of shows or movies.Gameplay's pretty neat too, think of the mario RPG games, like partners in time, for the gameplay, and practice those timed hits! It's pretty solid, there's a difficulty slider if you're into that, and I never got bored of the frankly hilarious visuals during the game. Seriously, it's south park meets super mario RPG!Don't expect to like this game if you're not a fan of south park though, but if you're not, then why were you thinking of buying the game anyway?

Posted: March 8, 2014
												If you like South Park and RPG games, it is awesome. If not, the awesomeness may vary.It is super offending, super vulgar and super surreal.The RPG elements are based on quests, side-quests, character progression, weapons and equipment gathering and turned-based combat with essential action elements. The environment is very often destructible, allowing you to avoid combat.  The mechanics are not complicated and quite easy to learn, so it does not stand in the way of the story.The story is simple. And I have not seen anything like it in a computer game. There are unforgettable scenes and scenarios with original elements, all of them funny as hell. The downside is, that without knowledge of the South Park series, much of the humor is “random” and “out of nowhere”. If you are a newcomer, the “alien abduction” scene from trailer is a great example of the humor. That gets you curios? Good, than look at some newer episodes of the series (available at your nearest internets) and make up your mind. It is not for everybody.Another issue is the game short play time and replayability. It took me 13 hours to finish and I see no reason to play it again.I would totally not recommend that game for children, but since I grew up on the series, that would be hypocritical.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												If you are a South Park fan, this is a must have. The Stick of Truth is a long South Park movie starring you. The game has tons of nods to previous episodes from the series, I spent several hours just exploring the town checking things out. The gameplay is similar to Paper Mario. It's a turn based RPG that gives you bonuses for well timed button presses durring attacks and defensive actions. These end up playing a vital role in surviving during your battles. The controls and certain "puzzles" can actually be a little confusing at times and some tutorials are obnoxious if you don't put in the correct inputs.  Unfortuneatley the game is very short for an RPG style game. If you do just the main story line you may easily come in under 10 hours. If you do all of the extra content you might be able to squeeze out 20 hours. By the end of the game I was sastified with all the hype that I carried coming into the release of this game having laughed myself silly several times through the course of the game. So in Summation:Buy it now if your a HUGE fan of South Park, you will not be displeased with the story, otherwise pick it up during the upcoming steam sale.
